name: Unix Section 7 Manual Page
summary: Learn about .7 files and view a list of programs that open them.

windows.name: Open over 400 file formats with File Viewer Plus.Free Download

content: Man pages are system-level documentation that describes the inner workings of a Unix-like operating system. These pages are typically grouped into sections that contain a related set of documentation.

The seventh section of most Unix manuals, however, contains miscellaneous important pieces of information that do not fit neatly into the manual's other seven categories. Each page of that section is saved as a 7 file.
NOTE: Other sections' Unix man pages use the .1, .2, .3, .4, .5, .6, and .8 extensions. Man pages are also commonly compressed into .GZ files (which may use the .gz.# extension).

description: A 7 file is a Unix manual page (man page) that can be accessed using the man utility. It describes a miscellaneous piece of system information. For example, the file boot.7 describes the system boot process.

instructions: In Unix-like OSes, you can open a 7 file by calling the man utility using the name of the file. For example, to open boot.7, enter man boot(7).
Since 7 files are plain text files, you can also open them in any text editor, such as Vim (Linux, Mac), Microsoft Notepad (Windows), and Apple TextEdit (Mac).

images.alt: Screenshot of a .7 file in Microsoft Visual Studio Code
images.caption: 7 file open in Microsoft Visual Studio Code
